title: Introduction to easytable
text: easytable package creates publication-ready regression tables multiple formats single function call. vignette demonstrates key features using Palmer Penguins dataset.

title: Introduction to easytable
text: Let’s start simple example using Palmer Penguins dataset. ’ll model penguin body mass function flipper length, species, island.
code: # Fit three nested models m1 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm, data = penguins) m2 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm + species, data = penguins) m3 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm + species + island, data = penguins)  # Create named list models <- list(   "Model 1" = m1,   "Model 2" = m2,   "Model 3" = m3 )

title: Introduction to easytable
text: default output format Word, using flextable package: creates formatted table can : - Viewed RStudio - Saved Word flextable::save_as_docx() - Included R Markdown Word documents

title: Introduction to easytable
text: Use heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors robust.se parameter: automatically uses HC-robust standard errors via lmtest sandwich packages. output includes note indicating robust SEs used. use robust SE: - Heteroskedasticity suspected detected - Large sample sizes asymptotic properties apply - Published standards field require

title: Introduction to easytable
text: Instead raw coefficients, can report average marginal effects (AME): Important notes marginal effects: - Intercept excluded (meaningful AME) - Use Model 2+ (need least one covariate beyond constant) - Interpretation: unit change X → change E[Y]
code: # Marginal effects (note: requires margins package) easy_table(models[2:3], output = "markdown", margins = TRUE)

title: Introduction to easytable
text: can use together: computes marginal effects robust standard errors.
code: easy_table(   models[2:3],   output = "markdown",   robust.se = TRUE,   margins = TRUE )

title: Introduction to easytable
text: many control variables (e.g., many factor levels), can group show presence/absence rather individual coefficients: Instead showing: - speciesChinstrap - speciesGentoo - islandDream - islandTorgersen table shows: - species: Y (indicating presence) - island: Y (indicating presence) especially useful : - Factor variables many levels - Time location fixed effects - variable want indicate presence without showing coefficients
code:
# Add more controls m4 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm + bill_length_mm, data = penguins) m5 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm + bill_length_mm + species + island,          data = penguins)  models_controls <- list(   "Baseline" = m4,   "With Controls" = m5 )  # Group species and island as control variables easy_table(   models_controls,   output = "markdown",   control.var = c("species", "island") ) #> [1] "|term              |      Baseline       |    With Controls     |
|:-----------------|:-------------------:|:--------------------:|

(531.01) |
|flipper_length_mm |   48.14 ***
(2.01)   |    27.76 ***
(3.2)    |
|bill_length_mm    |   6.05    
(5.18)    |   61.46 ***
(7.15)    |
|                  |                     |                      |
|                  |                     |                      |
|species           |                     |          Y           |

|N                 |         342         |         342          |
|R sq.             |        0.76         |         0.82         |
|Adj. R sq.        |        0.76         |         0.82         |


*Significance: ***p < .01; **p < .05; *p < .1*"

title: Introduction to easytable
text: can export underlying data table CSV: useful : - Archiving raw results - processing software - Sharing collaborators need raw numbers
code: easy_table(   models,   output = "word",   csv = "penguin_regression_results" ) # Creates: penguin_regression_results.csv

title: Introduction to easytable
text: ’s comprehensive example combining features:
code: # Fit models with controls m_baseline <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm + bill_length_mm,                  data = penguins)  m_full <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm + bill_length_mm +                species + island + sex,              data = na.omit(penguins))  models_full <- list(   "Baseline" = m_baseline,   "Full Model" = m_full )  # Create publication-ready table easy_table(   models_full,   output = "word",   robust.se = TRUE,   control.var = c("species", "island", "sex"),   highlight = TRUE,   csv = "final_results" )

title: Introduction to easytable
text: bottom table: - N: Number observations - R sq.: R-squared (proportion variance explained) - Adj. R sq.: Adjusted R-squared (penalized number predictors) - AIC: Akaike Information Criterion (lower better; model comparison)

title: Introduction to easytable
text: Use descriptive model names:
code: # Good models_named <- list(   "Baseline" = m1,   "Add Species" = m2,   "Full Model" = m3 )  # Less clear models_numbered <- list(   "Model1" = m1,   "Model2" = m2,   "Model3" = m3 )

title: Introduction to easytable
text: Use control.var : - many factor levels (e.g., 50 states, 100 countries) - Including fixed effects (time, location) - Control variables aren’t main focus - want compact table Don’t use control.var : - want show specific coefficient estimates - 2-3 levels - variable key predictor interest

title: Introduction to easytable
text: general, use robust.se = TRUE : - cross-sectional data potential heteroskedasticity - Sample size reasonably large (n > 30) - want conservative Don’t use : - ’ve explicitly modeled heteroskedasticity (e.g., WLS) - Small sample sizes (asymptotic properties may hold) - Time series data (use HAC errors instead, currently supported)

title: Create publication-ready regression tables in multiple formats — easy_table
code: easy_table(   model_list,   output = "word",   csv = NULL,   robust.se = FALSE,   control.var = NULL,   margins = FALSE,   highlight = FALSE )

title: Create publication-ready regression tables in multiple formats — easy_table
text: model_list named list statistical models (lm glm objects). Example: list(Model1 = m1, Model2 = m2) output Character string specifying output format. One : "word" - Microsoft Word via flextable (default) "markdown" - Markdown Quarto/RMarkdown "latex" - LaTeX PDF output csv Character string CSV file export (without .csv extension). NULL (default), CSV created. robust.se Logical. Use robust standard errors (HC type)? Default FALSE. Requires packages: lmtest, sandwich control.var Character vector variable names group "control variables". collapsed single rows showing "Y" presence instead individual coefficients. Default NULL. margins Logical. Compute average marginal effects (AME)? Default FALSE. Requires package: margins highlight Logical. Highlight significant coefficients (positive green, negative red)? Default FALSE. Works best Word output.

title: Create publication-ready regression tables in multiple formats — easy_table
text: Depends output: "word" - flextable object "markdown" - Character string markdown table "latex" - Character string LaTeX table code

title: Create publication-ready regression tables in multiple formats — easy_table
text: function extracts coefficients, standard errors, p-values model, adds significance stars (*** p<.01, ** p<.05, * p<.1), includes model fit statistics (N, R-squared, Adjusted R-squared, AIC). Control variables can grouped show presence/absence rather individual coefficients factor level transformation.

title: Create publication-ready regression tables in multiple formats — easy_table
text: Always required: broom, dplyr Word output: flextable Markdown/LaTeX: knitr, optionally kableExtra enhanced formatting Robust SE: lmtest, sandwich Marginal effects: margins

title: Create publication-ready regression tables in multiple formats — easy_table
code: if (FALSE) { # Load example data library(palmerpenguins) data(penguins)  # Fit models m1 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm, data = penguins) m2 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm + species, data = penguins) m3 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm + species + island, data = penguins) models <- list(Model1 = m1, Model2 = m2, Model3 = m3)  # Word output (default) easy_table(models)  # Markdown for Quarto/RMarkdown easy_table(models, output = "markdown")  # LaTeX for PDF easy_table(models, output = "latex")  # With robust standard errors easy_table(models, output = "word", robust.se = TRUE)  # Group species and island as control variables easy_table(models, output = "markdown", control.var = c("species", "island"))  # Highlight significant results easy_table(models, output = "word", highlight = TRUE)  # Export to CSV as well easy_table(models, output = "latex", csv = "regression_results") }

title: easytable 2.0.0

title: easytable 2.0.0

title: easytable 2.0.0
